questions.question: If he …………………, we will be shocked.
questions.description: When the verb in the if clause is in the simple present tense, we use will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had known, I ………………. you straightaway.
..................... seen such a mess.
questions.description: When the sentence begins with a negative expression, the auxiliary verb goes before the subject.

questions.question: I ..................... tea in the morning.
questions.description: The adverb goes before the main verb.

questions.question: Would you mind my ………………… the window?
You …………………. to find the time to do all the things you want to.
questions.description: Ought is the only modal followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: If you don’t want to go, you ………………..
You needn’t …………………. it.
questions.description: When need is used as a modal auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: If you asked more politely, I ............................ you some money.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the simple past tense, we use would + infinitive in the main clause.
